thread.title: Ready to serve public and country
thread.title_full: Ready to serve public and country

author: JASTIN AHMAD TARMIZI
title: Ready to serve public and country
text:
by jastin ahmad tarmizi 
KUALA LUMPUR: All his life K. Kabinveerapan knew he wanted to be a police officer and he expects his law degree will stand him in good stead. 
Armed with a law degree from University of Northumbria in Newcastle, Britain, the 22-year-old from Selangor joined the police force last year. 
Yesterday, Kabinveerapan was the youngest of 596 cadet inspectors who graduated as probationary inspectors after nine months of intense training. 
“Joining the police force has definitely been my ambition as I was inspired by many notable figures. 
“I am confident that a police officer with a knowledge of the law would play a more effective role. 
“That’s the main reason I studied law to serve the public and country,” he said during the graduation ceremony at the Police Training Centre (Pulapol) here. Proud moment: New probationary inspectors in a march-past during their graduation ceremony at the Police Training Centre in Kuala Lumpur. — Bernama 
He said his goal was to ensure that the force provided the public with world class policing and made Malaysia a safer place. 
Like Kabinveerapan, it was a proud moment for Wan Yunus Wan Morni who clinched the Best Academic Award. 
Asked about his training, the 26-year-old from Sarawak said that it was a hard nine months. 
“Although the training was tough, it taught me discipline as well as how to be physically and mentally strong. 
“Now, I’m proud that I have graduated,” he said, adding that he was pleased to have won the award. 
Another cadet inspector who graduated yesterday was 31-year-old Lam Chee Mun, who is a Master’s degree holder. 
Lam said she left her job as an administration executive to join the force as it had been her ambition for some time.
